intro: Amphisiphon, commonly known as the creeping bellflower, is a genus of flowering plants in the Campanulaceae family. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit and produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically blue or purple in color. The leaves are usually opposite and have a rough, hairy texture. Amphisiphon species are often found in rocky or sandy soils in temperate regions. They are valued in horticulture for their ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in challenging environments.
